.class public auto ansi beforefieldinit UITableView extends MonoTouch.UIKit.UIScrollView implements class MonoTouch.Foundation.INSCoding, class MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.INativeObject, class MonoTouch.UIKit.IUIDataSourceTranslating, class System.IDisposable

Docs.summary: A table view is used to display and edit hierarchical lists of information. A UITableView is limited to a single column because it is designed for a small screen.
Docs.remarks:
is a subclass of  that allows users to scroll the table vertically (the closely-related  class allows for horizontal scrolling and complex two-dimensional layouts). The table consists of  objects that are used to render the rows of the table. These cells have content -- labels, images, etc. -- and can also show accessories such as disclosure arrows or inputs controls. s can enter an edit-mode in which rows can be inserted, deleted, and reordered.
      
      

        The Xamarin article 
      
        Working with Tables
       provides guidance on all aspects of  use. 
      

For most use-cases, it is not necessary for application developers to subclass  or , which provide the generic table behavior. Instead, application developers will generally subclass  to populate a table and, often,  to customize appearance and row behavior.
Table Parts and Functionality
Classes Overview
The primary classes used to display table views are:
ClassResponsibility

            A view that contains a collection of cells inside a scrolling container. The table view typically uses the entire screen in an iPhone app but may exist as part of a larger view on the iPad (or appear in a popover).  
          

            A view that represents a single cell (or row) in a table view. There are four built-in cell types and it is possible to create custom cells both in C# or with Interface Builder.
          

            Xamarin.iOS-exclusive abstract class that provides all the methods required to display a table, including row count, returning a cell view for each row, handling row selection and many other optional features. You must subclass this to get a  working. ( combines  and . These classes are still available if the application developer chooses not to use .)
          

            Contains Row and Section properties that uniquely identify the position of a cell in a table.

            A ready-to-use  that has a  hardcoded as its view and made accessible via the  property. 

            If the table does not occupy the entire screen you can add a  to any  with its  property set appropriately.
Components of a UITableView
There are two  styles: Plain and Grouped. The Plain style allows the section headers and footers to remain visible as the section is scrolled through, and can optionally support an index that appears along the right edge to quickly scroll to a specific section. The Grouped style displays sections in rounded-rectangles that visually group the rows, and provides a default background image behind the scrolling list. The style of the  is specified as an argument to the  constructor and cannot be changed.  Grouped tables should not provide an index.
Tables consist of the following parts:ElementAccessed via:Type
Table Header
Section Header
Cells (also called Rows)
Section Footer
Index[]
Edit mode (includes ‘swipe to delete’ and drag handles to change row order)
Table Footer
Section rows, headers, footers, edit controls and the index are displayed as follows:

Populating Table Cells
s are designed to work efficiently with tables with thousands of rows. In order to achieve this, each  maintains a reusable cache of s only a few items larger than can be shown on the screen at any given time.
      
A  object is responsible for managing the relationship between the relatively few s and the data is to be displayed. The 's  and  methods allow the  to request only the data necessary for the cells on the screen. A specific cell is identified by an , whose  and properties will specify a unique cell.
As cells are about to be scrolled onto the screen, the  automatically calls the  method of the  object assigned to the  property of the  (or, if the application developer prefers, the  method of the  object referred to by the  property). 
The application developer's responsibilities when overriding  changed with the introduction of iOS 6. Application developers targeting iOS 6 and later should register a  for reuse with the  by calling either the  or  method. Once that is done, application developers do not need to check for null in their override of the  method.
If application developers are using the  with their own subclass of , that implementation must override the  constructor and call the base constructor (i.e., MyTableViewCell(IntPtr handle) : base(handle){}).
The application developer overrides the  method so that it:
Attempts to retrieve a previously-allocated  from the ;
If programming in iOS 5 and earlier, if that fails, initializes a new  of the appropriate type;
Change the state of the retrieved-or-created  so that it reflects the values appropriate for the passed-in .
          
Since the  method will be called whenever a cell comes into view, application developers should avoid unnecessary computation.
The 's reuse queue is accessed via the  method, which takes a  identifying the type of  to retrieve. In iOS 5 and earlier, that method may return , in which case the application developer should instantiate a new . In iOS 6 and later, while initializing the , the application developer must use either  or  to associate a  type and it's reuse identifier so that the method  can instantiate instances as necessary.
The following shows a simple example of the  method:
          public override UITableViewCell GetCell (UITableView tableView, NSIndexPath indexPath)
          {
          //Attempt to retrieve previously-allocated cell
          var cell = tableView.DequeueReusableCell (this.cellTypeIdentifier);
          //The following check and code-block only necessary in applications that do not use RegisterClassforCellReuse or RegisterNibForCellReuse
          if (cell == null) {
          //No reusable cell, so initialize a new one
          cell = new UITableViewCell (UITableViewCellStyle.Default, this.cellTypeIdentifier);
          cell.Tag = Environment.TickCount;
          }
          
          // Change the state of the cell
          cell.TextLabel.Text = //...etc...
          
          // return the cell
          return cell;
          }
          
Customizing Table Appearance
Other than the  property that specifies whether a  is grouped or continuous, the appearance of the table is primarily determined by the s, the s used for section headers and footers, and the s used for the  and  properties. The API documentation for  describes customization in detail. 
Highlighting and Selection
Selecting and highlighting in a  follows this sequence:User ActionUITableViewDelegate (UITableViewSource) MethodsUITableViewCell Properties
Nothing touchedHighlighted == ; Selected == 
Finger down in cell is called. If it returns , processing stops. 
          
 is called.
          Highlighted == ; Selected == 
Finger up is called. If it returns , processing stops. Otherwise, whatever  it returns will be highlighted.
          
 is called.  is called.
            
          Highlighted == ; Selected == 

Deselecting a  follows a similar sequence:User ActionUITableViewDelegate (UITableViewSource) MethodsUITableViewCell Properties
Nothing touched while some  is highlighted.Highlighted == ; Selected == 
Finger taps cell (Deselect gesture) is called. If it returns , processing stops. Otherwise, whatever  is returned will be deselected. 
          
 is called.
          Highlighted == ; Selected == 
UITableView caches  objects only for visible rows, but caches the heights of rows, headers and footers for the entire table. It is possible to create custom  objects with varying heights and custom layouts.
UITableView overrides  so that it calls  only when you create a new instance or when you assign a new  (or ).Reloading the table view clears current state (including the current selection). However if you explicitly call  it clears this state and any subsequent direct or indirect call to  does not trigger a reload.

.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSCoder coder) cil managed

Docs.param: The unarchiver object.
Docs.summary: A constructor that initializes the object from the data stored in the unarchiver object.

remarks.para: This constructor is provided to allow the class to be initialized from an unarchiver (for example, during NIB deserialization). This is part of the protocol.

If developers want to create a subclass of this object and continue to support deserialization from an archive, they should implement a constructor with an identical signature: taking a single parameter of type and decorate it with the [Export("initWithCoder:"] attribute declaration.
The state of this object can also be serialized by using the companion method, EncodeTo.

MemberSignature.Value: public UITableView (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed
protected UITableView (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t);
.method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed

Docs.param: Unused sentinel value, pass NSObjectFlag.Empty.
Docs.summary: Constructor to call on derived classes to skip initialization and merely allocate the object.

remarks.para: This constructor should be called by derived classes when they completely construct the object in managed code and merely want the runtime to allocate and initialize the NSObject. This is required to implement the two-step initialization process that Objective-C uses, the first step is to perform the object allocation, the second step is to initialize the object. When developers invoke the constructor that takes the NSObjectFlag.Empty they take advantage of a direct path that goes all the way up to NSObject to merely allocate the object's memory and bind the Objective-C and C# objects together. The actual initialization of the object is up to the developer.

This constructor is typically used by the binding generator to allocate the object, but prevent the actual initialization to take place. Once the allocation has taken place, the constructor has to initialize the object. With constructors generated by the binding generator this means that it manually invokes one of the "init" methods to initialize the object.
It is the developer's responsibility to completely initialize the object if they chain up using the NSObjectFlag.Empty path.

In general, if the developer's constructor invokes the NSObjectFlag.Empty base implementation, then it should be calling an Objective-C init method. If this is not the case, developers should instead chain to the proper constructor in their class.

The argument value is ignored and merely ensures that the only code that is executed is the construction phase is the basic NSObject allocation and runtime type registration. Typically the chaining would look like this:

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a pointer to an unmanaged Objective-C object. Developers should not invoke this method directly, instead they should call the GetNSObject method as it will prevent two instances of a managed object to point to the same native object.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool AllowsMultipleSelection { get; set; }
.property instance bool AllowsMultipleSelection

Docs.summary: Whether more than one row can be selected (outside of editing mode).
Docs.value: if multiple selection is prohibited, if it is allowed.

remarks.para: When this property is , a check mark is placed next to each row that is tapped. Tapping the row again removes the check mark.
Call to identify the selected rows.
The default value of this property is .

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool AllowsMultipleSelectionDuringEditing { get; set; }
.property instance bool AllowsMultipleSelectionDuringEditing

Docs.summary: Whether more than one row can be selected while in editing mode.
Docs.value: if multiple selection is prohibited, if it is allowed.

remarks.para: When this property is , a check mark is placed next to each row that is tapped. Tapping the row again removes the check mark. In addition, the UITableView does not query for editing styles when it goes into editing mode.
Call to identify the selected rows.
The default value of this property is .

Docs.value: if row selection is allowed, if not.
Docs.remarks: If (the default) then row selection is allowed. This property only affects cell selection when the table view is not in editing mode. To control selection in edting mode, use .

Docs.value: if row selection is allowed, if not. The default is .
Docs.remarks: If then row selection is allowed during editing. This property only affects cell selection when the table view is in editing mode. To control selection in normal mode, use .

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView.UITableViewAppearance Appearance { get; }
.property class MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView/UITableViewAppearance Appearance

Docs.summary: Strongly-typed property that returns the UIAppearance class for this class.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on this instance will affect the appearance of all instances of UITableView.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of UITableView, they should use the method.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView.UITableViewAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn (Type[] containers);
.method public static hidebysig class MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView/UITableViewAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn(class System.Type[] containers) cil managed

Docs.param: List of types that developers want to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance
Docs.summary: Returns a strongly typed UIAppearance for instances of this class when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.
Docs.returns: The appearance proxy object that developers can use to set properties when the given container hierarchy is active

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of UITableView when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of UITableView, they should use the method.
The following example shows how the AppearanceWhenContainedIn method works

example.code: var mySliders = UISlider.AppearanceWhenContainedIn (typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); mySliders.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView BackgroundView { get; set; }

Docs.summary: The background view of the table.
Docs.remarks: A table view's background view is automatically resized to match the size of the table view. The background view is placed as a subview of the table behind all cell, header and footer views.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void BeginUpdates ();
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void BeginUpdates() cil managed

Docs.summary: Call this method before inserting, updating or selecting rows that should be animated as one operation. must be called after the modifications are complete.

remarks.para: After calling this method, subsequent insertions, deletions and selection operations (eg. or ) will be animated simultaneously. This group of methods must conclude with a call to . These method pairs can be nested.

If the developer does not make the insertion, deletion and selection calls inside this block, table attributes such as row count might become invalid. Developers should not call within the group, otherwise they will need to perform any animations manually.

value.para: The instance of the MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewDelegate model class

remarks.para: The delegate instance assigned to this object will be used to handle events or provide data on demand to this class.
When setting the Delegate or WeakDelegate values events will be delivered to the specified instance instead of being delivered to the C#-style events

This is the strongly typed version of the object, developers should use the WeakDelegate property instead if they want to merely assign a class derived from NSObject that has been decorated with [Export] attributes.

Docs.param: Array of objects that identify which rows to delete.
What type of animation to use when deleting the rows (eg. fade out or slide out from bottom).

remarks.para: When this method is called inside an animation block defined by and , any insertions of rows or sections are deferred until after deletions have been processed. This happens regardless of the ordering of the insertion and deletion method calls within the animation block.

Application developers should prefer the use of , which returns a that is properly sized for the index path.

MemberSignature.Value: protected override void Dispose (bool disposing);
.method familyhidebysig virtual instance void Dispose(bool disposing) cil managed

param.name: disposing
param.para: If set to , the method is invoked directly and will dispose manage and unmanaged resources; If set to the method is being called by the garbage collector finalizer and should only release unmanaged resources.

Docs.summary: Releases the resources used by the UITableView object.

remarks.para: This Dispose method releases the resources used by the UITableView class.

This method is called by both the Dispose() method and the object finalizer (Finalize). When invoked by the Dispose method, the parameter disposing is set to and any managed object references that this object holds are also disposed or released; when invoked by the object finalizer, on the finalizer thread the value is set to .

Calling the Dispose method when the application is finished using the UITableView ensures that all external resources used by this managed object are released as soon as possible. Once developers have invoked the Dispose method, the object is no longer useful and developers should no longer make any calls to it.

For more information on how to override this method and on the Dispose/IDisposable pattern, read the ``Implementing a Dispose Method'' document at http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/fs2xkftw.aspx

Docs.summary: Whether the table view is in editing mode.
Docs.value: if the table is currently in editing mode, if not. The default is .
Docs.remarks: When this property is , the table view is in editing mode: cells may show an insertion or deletion control on their left side and a reordering control on the right (depending on how the cell is configured). Tapping a control causes the table view to invoke the method .

Docs.param: The encoder object where the state of the object will be stored
Docs.summary: Encodes the state of the object on the provided encoder

remarks.para: This method is part of the protocol and is used by applications to preserve the state of the object into an archive.
Users will typically create a and then invoke the which will call into this method

If developers want to allow their object to be archived, they should override this method and store their state in using the provided parameter. In addition, developers should also implement a constructor that takes an NSCoder argument and is exported with [Export ("initWithCoder:")]

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void EndUpdates ();
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void EndUpdates() cil managed

Docs.summary: Finalize a series of method calls that insert, update or select rows to animate as one operation. must be called before the modifications are made.
Docs.remarks: Call this method to bracket a series of table modifications (insert, delete or select rows) that began with . When EndUpdates is called the table view animates the operations simultaneously. Calls to and EndUpdates can be nested. If you make insertion, deletion or selection calls outside of a /EndUpdates block then table attributes such as row count might become invalid.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView.UITableViewAppearance GetAppearance<T> () where T : MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView;
.method public static hidebysig class MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView/UITableViewAppearance GetAppearance<(class MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView) T>() cil managed

Docs.typeparam: The type for which the UIAppearance proxy must be returned. This is a subclass of UITableView.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of UITableView.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on the returned object will affect the appearance of all classes and subclasses of the type parameter.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works
For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView.UITableViewAppearance GetAppearance<T> (MonoTouch.UIKit.UITraitCollection traits) where T : MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView;

Docs.param: Trait collection to match.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of UITableView.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of UITableView.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works
For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView.UITableViewAppearance GetAppearance<T> (MonoTouch.UIKit.UITraitCollection traits, Type[] containers) where T : MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView;

.method public static hidebysig class MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView/UITableViewAppearance GetAppearance<(class MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableView) T>(class MonoTouch.UIKit.UITraitCollection traits, class System.Type[] containers) cil managed

Docs.typeparam: The type for which the UIAppearance proxy must be returned. This is a subclass of UITableView.
Docs.param: Trait collection to match.
List of types that the developer wishes to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of UITableView that has the specified trait collection when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of UITableView that has the specified trait collection when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works

example.code: var myTheme = UITableView.GetAppearance<MyUITableViewSubclass> (myTraits, typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); myTheme.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void InsertRows (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexPath[] atIndexPaths, MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewRowAnimation withRowAnimation);

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void InsertRows(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexPath[] atIndexPaths, valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewRowAnimation withRowAnimation) cil managed

Docs.param: An array of s that indicate the desired insertion points.
What type of animation to use.
Docs.summary: Inserts rows into the .

remarks.para: UITableView calls the relevant methods (e.g., and related methods) immediately afterwards to get the cells and other content to display the visible rows.

When this method is called within a - animation block, any insertions of rows or sections are deferred until after deletions have been processed. This happens regardless of the ordering of the insertion and deletion method calls within the animation block..

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void InsertSections (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexSet sections, MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewRowAnimation withRowAnimation);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void InsertSections(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexSet sections, valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewRowAnimation withRowAnimation) cil managed

Docs.param: A set of section identifiers to insert. If a section already exists at a given index, it is moved up down one index location.
What type of animation to use when inserting the rows (eg. fade in or slide in from left)
Docs.summary: Inserts a section (or sections) from a table view, with an option to animate the operation.

remarks.para: UITableView calls the relevant methods immediately afterwards to get the cells and other content to display the visible rows.

When this method is called inside an animation block defined by and , any insertions of rows or sections are deferred until after deletions have been processed. This happens regardless of the ordering of the insertion and deletion method calls within the animation block.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void MoveRow (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexPath fromIndexPath, MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexPath toIndexPath);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void MoveRow(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexPath fromIndexPath, class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexPath toIndexPath) cil managed

Docs.param: An indicating the original row.
The desired location.
Docs.summary: Moves a row from to .

remarks.para: There is no function for moving an array of rows (in contrast to or ). The applicatin developer must instead repeatedly call this function. If this function is called within a - animation block, all the row manipulation will occur as a single animation.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void MoveSection (int fromSection, int toSection);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void MoveSection(int32 fromSection, int32 toSection) cil managed
public virtual void MoveSection (nint fromSection, nint toSection);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void MoveSection(valuetype System.nint fromSection, valuetype System.nint toSection) cil managed

Docs.param: Index of the section to move.
Destination index for the section. The section currently at this index is moved up or down to accomodate the moved section.
Docs.summary: Moves a section to a new location in the table view.

remarks.para: This method can be combined with other MoveSection, and operations within an animation block defined by and , so that all the changes occur in a single animation.

Unlike the insertion and deletion methods, moving a section does not use an animation paramter. Moved sections always animate straight from their starting position to their new position. Only one section can be moved per method call, however to move multiple sections application developers can call this method repeatedly within a - animation block.

MemberSignature.Value: public void RegisterClassForCellReuse (Type cellType, MonoTouch.Foundation.NSString reuseIdentifier);
.method public hidebysig instance void RegisterClassForCellReuse(class System.Type cellType, class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSString reuseIdentifier) cil managed

Docs.param: The type of a UITableViewCell to create when the specified reuseIdentifier is passed to DequeueReusableCell.
The reuse identifier.
Docs.summary: Registers a type to provide UITableViewCells for a specific reuseIdentifier.

remarks.para: Mono can use this method to register the type of a class that should be instantiated if the UITableView needs to create a new cell in response to a request in DequeueReusableCell for the specified reuseIdentifier.

Registering types with cell identifiers helps reduce the amount of code that you have to write in your GetCell method. It means that your GetCell method only needs to call DequeueReusableCell with the reuse identifier, and if there is no available cell, the UITableView will create an instance of the specified type and return it.
The type that you register must provide a constructor that takes an IntPtr constructor and needs to chain to the constructor.

MemberSignature.Value: public void RegisterClassForCellReuse (Type cellType, string reuseIdentifier);
.method public hidebysig instance void RegisterClassForCellReuse(class System.Type cellType, string reuseIdentifier) cil managed

Docs.param: To be added.
To be added.
Docs.summary: Registers the type for reuse, keyed by the identifier .

MemberSignature.Value: public void RegisterClassForHeaderFooterViewReuse (Type cellType, MonoTouch.Foundation.NSString reuseIdentifier);
.method public hidebysig instance void RegisterClassForHeaderFooterViewReuse(class System.Type cellType, class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSString reuseIdentifier) cil managed

Docs.param: The type of a UIView to create when the specified reuseIdentifier is passed to DequeueReusableCell.
The reuse identifier.
Docs.summary: Registers a type to provide UIViews for headers or footers for a specific reuseIdentifier.

remarks.para: You can use this method to register the type of a class that should be instantiated if the UITableView needs to create a new header or footer in response to a request in DequeueReusableHeaderFooterView for the specified reuseIdentifier.

Registering types with reuse identifiers helps reduce the amount of code that you have to write in your GetFooterView or GetHeaderView methods. It means that your code only needs to call DequeueReusableHeaderFooterView with the reuse identifier, and if there is no available cell, the UITableView will create an instance of the specified type and return it.
The type that you register must provide a constructor that takes an IntPtr constructor and needs to chain to the constructor.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void ReloadData ();
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ReloadData() cil managed

Docs.summary: Reloads the rows and sections in the table view.

remarks.para: This method reloads all the data in the table, including cells, headers, footers and the index array. For efficiency, only visible rows are have their cells loaded and displayed.
A table view's calls this method when it wants to completely reload data. This method should not be called inside other methods that insert or delete rows, especially within a - animation block.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void ReloadRows (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexPath[] atIndexPaths, MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewRowAnimation withRowAnimation);

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ReloadRows(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexPath[] atIndexPaths, valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewRowAnimation withRowAnimation) cil managed

Docs.param: An array of objects that indicate which rows to reload.
The type of animation to use. The animation chosen affects both the way the old cell is animated out as well as how the new cell is animated into view.
Docs.summary: Reloads specific rows with the given animation effect.

remarks.para: Reloading a row means the data source is asked for a new cell for that row, which the table animates into place (animating the old cell off screen). Use this method to alert the user that the value of the cell is changing. If notifying the user is not important simply get the cell for a particular row and update its value.

When this method is called within a - animation block it behaves like - the indexes passed to the method are specified in the state of the table view prior to any updates. This happens regardless of the order of the insertion, deletion and reloading method calls within the animation block.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void ReloadSectionIndexTitles ();
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ReloadSectionIndexTitles() cil managed

Docs.summary: Reloads the index bar long the right edge of a table view.
Docs.remarks: Use this method to update the index after inserting or deleting sections, without having to reload the entire table.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void ReloadSections (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexSet sections, MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewRowAnimation withRowAnimation);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ReloadSections(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexSet sections, valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewRowAnimation withRowAnimation) cil managed

Docs.param: The sections to be reloaded.
Specifies which animation effect to use. This determines how the old sections are animated out as well as how the new sections are animated into view.
Docs.summary: Reloads specific sections with an animation effect.

remarks.para: Reloading a section means the data source is asked for news cell for the specified sections, which the table animates into place (animating the old cells off screen). Use this method to alert the user that the cells in the given sections are changing. If notifying the user is not important simply get the relevant cells and update their values directly.

When this method is called within a - animation block it behaves like - the indexes passed to the method are specified in the state of the table view prior to any updates. This happens regardless of the order of the insertion, deletion and reloading method calls within the animation block.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual float RowHeight { get; set; }
.property instance float32 RowHeight
public virtual nfloat RowHeight { get; set; }
.property instance valuetype System.nfloat RowHeight

Docs.summary: The height of each row in this UITableView.

remarks.para: This property can be set if the has not been implemented. If the row height is not set explicity the table view uses a default value.

There are performance implications to using instead of this property: every time a table view is displayed it calls for each of its rows. This can result in poor performance when the table has a large number of rows (for example, 1000 rows or more).
If every row in a table has the same height, use this property. If rows have different heights (for example, they are sized around a variable amount of text) then is more appropriate.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void ScrollToNearestSelected (MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewScrollPosition atScrollPosition, bool animated);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ScrollToNearestSelected(valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewScrollPosition atScrollPosition, bool animated) cil managed

Docs.param: Position that the target row should appear (e. top, middle, bottom) once the scrolling is complete.
to animate the scroll, if the table view should just jump immediately to the new position.
Docs.summary: Automatically scrolls the rows so that the selected row nearest to a given position is moved to that position.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void ScrollToRow (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexPath indexPath, MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewScrollPosition atScrollPosition, bool animated);

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ScrollToRow(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexPath indexPath, valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewScrollPosition atScrollPosition, bool animated) cil managed

Docs.param: Identifies which row should appear . You can pass to scroll to a section with zero rows.
Position that the target row should appear (e. top, middle, bottom) once the scrolling is complete.
to animate the scroll, if the table view should just jump immediately to the new position.
Docs.summary: Automatically scrolls the table view until the specified row appears in the required position.
Docs.remarks: Calling this method does not trigger , which would normally occur after a programmatically-invoked UI operation.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.Foundation.NSString SelectionDidChangeNotification { get; }
.property class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSString SelectionDidChangeNotification

Docs.summary: Notification constant for SelectionDidChange
Docs.value: NSString constant, should be used as a token to NSNotificationCenter.

remarks.para: This constant can be used with the to register a listener for this notification. This is an NSString instead of a string, because these values can be used as tokens in some native libraries instead of being used purely for their actual string content. The 'notification' parameter to the callback contains extra information that is specific to the notification type.
If you want to subscribe to this notification, you can use the convenience . method which offers strongly typed access to the parameters of the notification.
The following example shows how to use the strongly typed Notifications class, to take the guesswork out of the available properties in the notification:
The following example shows how to use the notification with the DefaultCenter API:

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SelectRow(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSIndexPath indexPath, bool animated, valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewScrollPosition scrollPosition) cil managed

param.name: indexPath
param.para: Identifies the row to be selected.

Docs.param: to animate the selection and position change, if the change should occur immediately.
Position that the selected row should be scrolled to (top, middle, bottom).
Docs.summary: Selects the given row, optionall scrolling the row to a specific location.

remarks.para: Calling this method does not trigger nor will it send notifications.

example.para: Passing . will result in no scrolling (despite that constant normally causing minimal scrolling). To scroll to the newly selected row with minimum scrolling, select the row using this method with then call also with .

Docs.param: to enter editing mode, to end editing. The default is .
to animate the transition to or from editing mode, or to change modes immediately.
Docs.summary: Turns editing mode on or off.

remarks.para: Calling this method with == , the table view enters editing mode and calls on each visible row's object.
In editing mode the cells might show
The (or ) can selectively exclude cells from editing mode by returning from .

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObject WeakDelegate { get; set; }
.property instance class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObject WeakDelegate

Docs.summary: An object that can respond to the delegate protocol for this type

value.para: The instance that will respond to events and data requests.

remarks.para: The delegate instance assigned to this object will be used to handle events or provide data on demand to this class.
When setting the Delegate or WeakDelegate values events will be delivered to the specified instance instead of being delivered to the C#-style events

Methods must be decorated with the [Export ("selectorName")] attribute to respond to each method from the protocol. Alternatively use the Delegate method which is strongly typed and does not require the [Export] attributes on methods.
